stream_context.summary: Kaze spent the session inside the Wild-West course, wiring up several NPCs: Dry-Bones-style desert skeletons, a saloon piano player, and a special “cow Boshi” duel event.  Most of the code/animation work revolved around making the enemies feel lively, tuning line-of-sight AI, footsteps, camera framing, and designing the duel countdown dialog.  He also teased an un-shown collaboration level for a future course.

development_findings.summary: Implemented desert Dry Bones enemy: line-of-sight pursuit, acceleration/deceleration tweaks, animation speed that scales with walk speed, zombie-style walk cycle, adaptive stop-chase logic, and synced footstep sounds.
development_findings.quote: "Usually I scale animations with the walking speed – it’s the easiest thing to make good-looking."

development_findings.summary: Designed ‘cow Boshi’ duel: NPC asks Mario for a quick-draw shoot-out, counts down "3-2-1-go", throws an egg while Mario fires a cork gun.  Reaction window lengthens after each player loss to accommodate monitor lag and varied reflexes.
development_findings.quote: "Every consequent loss makes him wait slightly longer – some people are going to be unable to do this on the first try."

development_findings.summary: Started integrating a saloon piano-player shy guy; reduced texture size and re-mapped UVs to cut memory usage before handing the model back to Zeina for animation.
development_findings.quote: "The reason I want small textures is because it saves a lot of memory."

development_findings.summary: Teased a collaboration level with Aeza; both will contribute a stage that will appear in the SEC build, effectively "double-cashing in" on its popularity.
development_findings.quote: "He’s making a level and I’m making a level… so we can just double cash in, you know what I mean."

development_findings.summary: Performance philosophy: heavy use of cache, many custom optimisations not present in HexaMario64; current frame-rate notably higher.  New F3DX microcode still runs slow and will be debugged with Sauraen.
development_findings.quote: "I don’t think any other fan game actually hits 70 % of the frame-rate the hardware could give them had they done everything right."

development_findings.summary: Considering adding a rideable Yoshi but undecided.
Total text count projected at ~500 boxes, roughly triple the original game, due to narrative and tutorial needs.

context_findings.summary: Kaze frames each hack as an experiment to learn new techniques rather than purely to entertain or profit.
context_findings.quote: "I always make something with the idea I'm going to learn from this and become even better."

context_findings.summary: He values intrinsic motivation in game design; criticises titles that only provide extrinsic rewards.
context_findings.quote: "Playing Pokémon feels like a job … but in Tears of the Kingdom you build a machine for fun – that’s pure intrinsic motivation."

context_findings.summary: Shows irritation when chat asks mundane or parasocial questions, reflecting a desire to keep streams focused on meaningful discussion.
context_findings.quote: "Talking about what you ate feels so incredibly narcissistic to me – who gives a---?"

context_findings.summary: Maintains a strict workout regimen (push-pull-legs every four days) and occasionally shares fitness advice.
Warns viewers about downloading random ROMs and Project64 builds due to virus risk, indicating ongoing awareness of legal/technical pitfalls.

biobak.summary: Reviewed Kaze’s secret collaboration level privately and provided immediate feedback in DMs.
Supplied hot-key/workflow advice for unpacking resources inside the editor.

zeina.summary: Created and supplied animations for Dry Bones enemy, the piano shy guy, and ‘cow Boshi’.
zeina.quote: "Zayna animated this guy here – the Dry Bones guy will be so happy."

zeina.summary: Active in chat, giving live feedback and holding Kaze’s credit card to order dev hardware.

key_stories.title: Teaching Dry Bones to Walk
key_stories.summary: Kaze takes Zeina’s new Dry Bones model and turns it into a fully functional desert enemy with zombie-like gait, custom sounds, and smarter chase logic.
key_stories.challenge: Make a visually charming but fair enemy that fits the Wild-West desert.
key_stories.process: Adjusted animation speeds, added step sounds, line-of-sight checks, and tuned acceleration/deceleration until the motion felt right.
key_stories.outcome: Enemy is now complete except for a crumble sound effect to be added late in development.
key_stories.key_quote: "Most of the time when an animation looks off it’s because it’s in slow motion somehow."

key_stories.title: Designing the Boshi Quick-Draw
key_stories.summary: A cowboy-themed Yoshi challenges Mario to a quick-draw duel.  Kaze scripts dialog in Western slang, programs the countdown, and plans adaptive timing to ensure accessibility.
key_stories.challenge: Create a reaction-time mini-game that feels tense but isn’t impossible for players with slower monitors or reflexes.
key_stories.process: Wrote dialog tree, set up camera framing, coded variable wait time after each failure, and defined attack assets (egg vs cork gun).
key_stories.outcome: Core logic complete; needs final animations and balance tuning.
key_stories.key_quote: "Every time you lose the game gets a little bit easier – just to make sure everyone can beat it."

key_stories.title: The Secret Collab with Aeza
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Aeza each build a level that will ship in the SEC, effectively giving both creators cross-exposure.
key_stories.challenge: Capitalize on SEC hype without revealing spoilers.
key_stories.process: Kaze builds a level he was already planning, shares private previews with Biobak for critique, and keeps footage off-stream.
key_stories.outcome: Level looks "really good" per Kaze; still under wraps.
key_stories.key_quote: "We can just double cash in – the good old Kaze strat."

key_stories.title: Vanquishing Performance Gremlins
key_stories.summary: Kaze notices VS Code suddenly starts giving correct IntelliSense and celebrates; also debates emulator choice and microcode slow-downs.
key_stories.challenge: Maintain high frame-rate and stable toolchain on aging hardware.
key_stories.process: Compares his repo’s cache-heavy optimizations against HexaMario64, plans joint debugging session with Sauraen on F3DX, and sticks to Project64 1.6 despite community pressure.
key_stories.outcome: Tools now work; microcode issue postponed.
key_stories.key_quote: "Somehow randomly my VS Code started working – that one guy will be so happy."
